Overview of the Whole Crusade
Pt.1
>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ydVFqpbIIwA&ab_channel=EpicHistoryTV

Battle of Ascalon
>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2loWiJSUDIQ&ab_channel=BazBattles
>The First Crusade Ends and the Crusader-Seljuk Wars begin
In Other News
>The Modena Cathedral is founded and dedicated to saint Germanicus
>Pope Urban II dies from natural causes 5 months before Jerusalem is reclaimed.
>El Cid dies during the siege of his capital of Valencia, likely from famine or sickness.
>Peter Barhalemew, the man who found the Holy Lance, dies in a failed attempt at an Ordeal of Fire where he claims he was hurt only after the ordeal was completed.
>The Taifa of Tortosa is overrun by the Almoravids, ending its existence permanently
>The Crusader States of the Principality of Galilee and the Kingdom of Jerusalem are established.
>The Knights Hospitaller is established as well as the Diocese of Lydda and Ramla.
>A Cathedral is built in Sicily and a Basilica in Milan.
>The Village of Holohory in Ukraine is first mentioned by name, it used to be home to 2,339 people in 1968, now it barely homes 658

>Byzantine Status; New Friend; The Fatimids.

>Story Idea; It’s over, the streets of Jerusalem run red with the blood of heretics and heathens alike, from those Jewish Rats, to the Fennecs, Camels, and Horses that make up those filthy Muslims, but the worst are the Gulls and Lizards of those heretic eastern churches. It matters little to you, you aren’t in Jerusalem anymore, in fact you are at Ascalon, where the Dragon you had prayed to Saint George to save you from stands before you with a cross around her neck and arms open to you. She is yours, first a prisoner but now as a wife for stability reasons as instructed and approved by Bohemund. Your patron died, leaving his wealth to you as he had no heir and adopted you in the eyes of your Norman court. You make a stop at Antioch before you leave, and leave a coin for the Knights of Saint Lazarus. On the way back to Scilly your wife lays atop you, cool in the already frigid waters of the Mediterranian winter. Upon arriving you are welcomed as a hero, a dozen squires lined up to be trained. But you are far from able, you won the battle, and the prize of a lifetime in the form of your wife, but now your body is nearly broken, the life you spent as a sergeant in the service of the Normans, and now the four years as a crusader has weakened you. You can train a squire, but not well enough alone, you need an order, something relevant, and Order to Saint George, Come the Feast of Saint Valentine you assemble some of the petty nobles you befriended during the crusade, and two months into the beginning of a new century, you found it, the Order of Saint George, the Dragon Layer.

This Crusade bit has been rather fun in all fairness, I now dub myself the Marshall of the Order of Saint Kevin, Patron Saint of Crows, Ravens, and Blackbirds

>read The Leaves of Fall in one sitting, absolutely gripped from start to finish
>spend ages typing out a word-limit post about how much I enjoyed it
>computer fucking crashes as I'm selecting an image

So anyway, The Leaves of Fall is legitimately the best story I've ever read from these threads and I have virtually nothing negative to say about it. The ridiculous and cheesy 'goth kids out to destroy the world with an evil ritual' plot was pulled off damn near flawlessly, all the characters were great and I got invested in all of them, and Sam in particular was wonderfully written - adorable, tragic, and with tons of character growth as the story goes on. Watching Sam's confidence blossom was wonderful, particularly as a lot of characters in her position in these sorts of stories sadly don't get much in the way of character development at all and remain a doormat for the protagonist to constantly save the whole time. I was also impressed at how well the sections about Sam's terribly abusive home life were treated, especially given the overall lighthearted, cheesy 80's movie tone that (most of) the rest of the story has.

If the author happens to be lurking around here and sees this post, I really want to thank them for creating such a wonderful story and sharing it with the world for us to enjoy. It was easily 100% worth every hour spent reading and then some.

Anonymous Tue 13 Oct 2020 19:56:56 No.33383376 Report
Quoted By: >>33383459 >>33383500
>>33383284
I agree, but the idea is that creating for creating's sake is well and nice and it can go a long way, but are social animals and putting this much thought and effort into something without recognition isn't particularly good.

Imagine you are a street artist and you have all your work on the sidewalk for people to look at. There's thousands of people passing by every day, most of them don't care, and at best one of them gives it a glance and passes on. Once in a blue moon one guy stops and says "wow, cool stuff man".

Now you could infer that the single fact that someone, somewhere has taken his time to read, enjoyed and gave feedback (or in the metaphor's case, stopped and looked at) the art piece someone else made is reward in itself, but when you spend years writing something and checking and re-checking and losing nights and sleep and overthinking and rewriting passages and doing it over and over and over, getting next to no feedback on it can be devastating.
Anonymous

  • Report

Anonymous Tue 13 Oct 2020 20:02:19 No.33383459 Report

You have a point there. The complete absence of feedback, or even a small "thanks" or "can't wait to read it" in response to an update, can really get to you in the long run. Every artist has that creeping doubt that they're not good enough, and it's easy to fall into bad habits of feeding that doubt when you feel like no-one cares about what you create

Anonymous Tue 13 Oct 2020 20:09:12 No.33383574 Report
Quoted By: >>33383667
>>33383500
>Though maybe it would help if writers spent more time writing and gave fewer larger updates rather than many small ones.
That's a double edged sword, many constant small updates keep jogging the memory of the story (and thus your works in general and you as a writer) in what is essentially a very fast forum where old posts are quite literally deleted and basically need to be recovered with a third party site.
I'd say that small updates are good for starting out when nobody knows who you are or what you're doing or what your shtick is, and after you've gained enough roots to be sure that people won't forget who you are or what you wrote if you don't update for 2/3 months, you go for the big updates.
That's just my opinion though, I am sure many authors differ on this.

Anonymous Tue 13 Oct 2020 23:16:45 No.33386519 Report

Ago's "On the Fringes" is one of my favorite stories on here. Whilst daydreaming during a slow moment at work, one running theme within it became obvious to me. Memory. Or, to be more specific, that memory is how we define ourselves. To avoid spoiling it for those who have not read it yet, I won't use particularly specific examples. Just about every character in the story is struggling with their memories, their perception of them, their identity, or some combination of the three. Through these case examples, and through character development, this relation is made apparent.

Oh and also I'm a sucker for reptilians (from big nagas to small kobolds) so there's that.

I think it'd be a balance of the two. There's generally a reason why anthros look so similar to their wild four-legged cousins, and that's because they'd have to be more genetically close to them than let's say, we are to apes. Sure we share a lot of DNA with them, but not enough to share their more baser-instincts. We still have those base instincts at our core, but given our heightened intelligence, we have a considerable amount of control over them. Anthros would still be able to have heat with human-level intelligence or close to it, but not on the same level as they would with their wild counterparts.
